I'm creating a bunch of utility classes in a project, and I stumbled across a bug in which utility classes are not being generated, if they're also used within some custom components/classes.

Issues.Title: v4 preflight theme variables aren't prefixed
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please provide all of the information requested below. We're a small team and without all of this information it's not possible for us to help and your bug report will be closed. -->
Versions:
- Tailwind: v4.0.9
- Vite: 5.2.11
- Node: 20.14.0
- Chrome, Mac OS

[Reproduction URL](https://play.tailwindcss.com/fPhQksGLVR)

If you look at the reproduction URL above (took awhile to prefix all those classes lol) you can see that the `--default-font-family` does not map to the prefixed `--font-sans` declared in the `@theme`. It seems that since `--default-font-family: var(--font-sans);` it isn't getting updated to map to the prefixed value later. This was not an issue in v3.

The workaround I have is to declare `--default-font-family` in my own `@layer base`:

```css
@layer base {
  html {
    --default-font-family: 'Salesforce Sans', Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;
  }
}
```

What ought to happen is the preflight reference points to the prefixed font so that the theme can correctly override it: `--default-font-family: var(--tw-font-sans);`
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "v4 preflight theme variables aren't prefixed" (#16945)

Issues.Title: `@tailwindcss/vite@^4.0.8` is not able to find classes from component based config and components
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please provide all of the information requested below. We're a small team and without all of this information it's not possible for us to help and your bug report will be closed. -->

**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?**

`v4.0.9` (`4.0.7` works fine)

**What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?**

- Vite `6.2.0`

**What version of Node.js are you using?**

`v22.13.1`

**What browser are you using?**

Chrome

**What operating system are you using?**

Debian (WSL2)

**Reproduction URL**

https://github.com/nachoaldamav/tailwind-debug-4.0.9

**Describe your issue**

With the change from the PR https://github.com/tailwindlabs/tailwindcss/pull/16631 loading config files and component as packages break the candidates search.

### Key points

- The config file (css) is loaded from `@my-org/tailwind-config/styles.css`.
- A button component loaded from `@my-org/button`.
- Theorically, using `@source "../node_modules/@my-org/button` would fix it, but it doesn't.
- This could be caused by pnpm `node_modules` structure, as the config file is not loaded from `node_modules/@my-org/tailwind-config/styles.css`, but from `node_modules/.pnpm/@my-org+tailwind-config@1.0.0/node_modules/@my-org/tailwind-config/styles.css`.
- About pnpm, it means that `@source` needs to be `../../../../../@my-org/button/dist` which is not very reliable.

I think re-opening this PR (https://github.com/tailwindlabs/tailwindcss/pull/16425) could fix this issue, maybe making the default be the FileSystem one and optionally the Module Graph system.

` // Both light and bold are applied at respective breakpoints // Utility + Arbitrary `

` // Both light and 600 are applied at respective breakpoints ----- #### Not Working Cases: // Arbitrary + Utility `

` // Only font-[300] is applied, md:font-bold is ignored // Arbitrary + Arbitrary `

` // Only font-[300] is applied, md:font-[600] is ignored // Similar issues with other properties `

` ----- ### Environment - Tailwind CSS version: 4.0.9 - Build tool: Vite - React version: 18.3.1 - Browser: Chrome 133.0.6943.142, Safari 18.1.1 - OS: macOS 15.1.1

Issues.Title: CLI instructions don't work with bun
Issues.Body:
https://tailwindcss.com/docs/installation/tailwind-cli

The CLI instructions tell users to run

```
npm install tailwindcss @tailwindcss/cli
npx @tailwindcss/cli -i ./src/input.css -o ./src/output.css --watch
```

The mix of npm and npx is interesting - the point of npx was to not install packages, right? Won't running npx install the package again?

Nevertheless, one can make this work with bun without using bunx by running the following:

```
bun add tailwindcss @tailwindcss/cli
bun run tailwindcss -i ./src/input.css -o ./src/output.css --watch
```

with the main change being `bun run tailwindcss` instead of `bunx @tailwindcss/cli`.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "CLI instructions don't work with bun" (#16922)

Issues.Title: Tailwind CSS CLI Binary Missing Since 4.0.0-alpha.1
Issues.Body:
Description of the Issue

Starting from Tailwind CSS 4.0.0-alpha.1, the CLI binary (tailwindcss) is missing, causing npx tailwindcss to fail.
This prevents users from using the Tailwind CLI when installed via npm.
üîé Steps to Reproduce

    Create a fresh project:

mkdir tailwind-test && cd tailwind-test
npm init -y

Install Tailwind CSS 4.0.0-alpha.1 (or later):

npm install -D tailwindcss@4.0.0-alpha.1 postcss autoprefixer

Check if the CLI binary exists:

ls -l node_modules/.bin/tailwindcss
ls -l node_modules/tailwindcss/bin
ls -l node_modules/tailwindcss/lib/cli.js

Try running the CLI:

    npx tailwindcss --help

üö® Expected Behavior

    The binary node_modules/.bin/tailwindcss should exist.
    Running npx tailwindcss should show the help output.

‚ùå Actual Behavior

    The binary is missing.
    npx tailwindcss fails with:

npm error could not determine executable to run

The binary is missing in:

    node_modules/.bin/tailwindcss
    node_modules/tailwindcss/bin
    node_modules/tailwindcss/lib/cli.js

‚úÖ Working & ‚ùå Broken Versions
Version	Status
‚úÖ 3.4.3	Works fine, binary exists
‚ùå 4.0.0-alpha.1	First broken version, binary missing
‚ùå 4.0.0	Still broken
‚ùå 4.0.8+	Still broken
üõ† System Information

npx tailwindcss --help # fails
node -v # 22.14.0
npm -v # 10.9.2
OS: Ubuntu 22.04

üìå Possible Cause

    The binary is not included in the published npm package starting with 4.0.0-alpha.1.
    This could be due to a build or publishing issue in the npm package.

üî• Next Steps:
‚úÖ Please confirm whether this is an (mysterious) intentional change or a bug.
‚úÖ If it's a bug, can we get a fix or an official workaround?

Issues.Title: `Cannot find module '../lightningcss.linux-x64-gnu.node'` in oven/bun:alpine docker image
Issues.Body:
**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?**

 v4.0.9

**What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?**

Next.js 15.1.7

**What version of Node.js are you using?**

v20.17.0

**Describe your issue**

It's related to https://github.com/oven-sh/bun/issues/17626. Tailwind uses `detect-libc@1.0.3` while bun is polyfilling `detect-libc` and uses `v2` API interface. This results in not detecting MUSL correctly.

Using docker image `oven/bun:alpine` the build of application with Tailwind v4 results in an error:

```
ResolveMessage: Cannot find module '../lightningcss.linux-x64-gnu.node' from '/app/node_modules/lightningcss/node/index.js'
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "`Cannot find module '../lightningcss.linux-x64-gnu.node'` in oven/bun:alpine docker image" (#16892)

Issues.Body:

Version - v4.0.6

Build tool - Next.js 15.1.7

**What version of Node.js are you using?**

Nodejs Version - v20.0.0

**What browser are you using?**
Browser - Google Chrome 

**What operating system are you using?**

Operation System - Windows11

**Reproduction URL**

Reproducntion URL - https://play.tailwindcss.com/rTe8nMV3GQ

**Describe your issue**

## Issue: Color Clashing in UI Affecting Readability & Accessibility

### Description
The current UI color scheme has noticeable clashes that impact readability and user experience. Certain elements have poor contrast, making text difficult to read and reducing accessibility compliance (e.g., WCAG guidelines). This can negatively affect users with visual impairments and general usability.

### Problem Areas Identified
- **Low contrast between text and background**, making readability difficult.
- **Color combinations that do not follow accessibility best practices** (e.g., red on blue or neon colors together).
- **Inconsistent color usage** across different sections, affecting UI consistency.

### Steps to Reproduce
1. Navigate to the affected page/component.
2. Observe text readability and color contrast.
3. Use an accessibility contrast checker to validate WCAG compliance.

### Expected Behavior
- Improved color choices that ensure **better readability and accessibility**.
- Compliance with **WCAG 2.1 guidelines** (minimum contrast ratio of 4.5:1 for normal text).
- Consistent color usage for a better UI experience.

### Proposed Solution
- Update the color palette to **maintain high contrast** for better readability.
- Ensure colors align with **brand identity** while improving accessibility.

### Labels
`bug` `accessibility` `UI/UX issue` `enhancement`
